message.content: A merism is a figure of speech in which an author or speaker describes something by using two extremes to convey the meaning of its entirety. It involves dividing a concept into its parts and then combining them to express a whole. This technique is often used in literature, poetry, and rhetoric to create vivid imagery or emphasize a point. For example, "from head to toe" or "from dawn to dusk" are both merisms that refer to the entirety of a person's body or a day, respectively. Merisms can be either cumulative (combining parts for emphasis) or distributive (separating something into two halves). They help create a more vivid and expressive way of describing an object or idea by highlighting its extent or range.
